This game is an absolutely awesome puzzler.  Hands down my favorite co-op puzzler.  Multitudes of player created levels provides an endless reason to return to playing, even if you take a long break.  The devs keep releasing patches and fixes for issues as they arise.

fun game to play with friends

You shouldn't be reading this review.

You should be experiencing an amazing game.

But if you want a short review in bullet point form then I can tell you this game has:

- Amazing puzzles and mechanics.
- Incredible level and sound design.
- A great sense of direction without waypoints (classic Valve).
- An awesome story with great funny characters.
- Amazing voice acting.
- Expert pacing.
- A great end-credits GLaDOS song.
- Some nice extra stuff like a comic book and funny videos.
- An awesome easy to use level creator.
- A single and multiplayer option to play user created levels.

This is an amazing experience you should not miss that I cannot recommend enough.
10/10. Interesting story, Great gameplay, Amazing soundtrack. The Most fun I've ever had in a single playthrough.

6/10 Decent:

Don‚Äôt kill me for offering a contrarian opinion here, but I think both Portal games are a victim of being overrated. I thoroughly enjoyed the first game, but not to the extent of the full whack of 10/10‚Äôs and ‚Äòbest game ever‚Äô accolades that fans throw at it ‚Äì it did, however, have an awesome villain and a fantastic ending song.

Portal 2 is a game of two halves. Initially, it kicks off by following on from the ending of Portal 1, and introduces the hilarious, Wheatley AI, a goofball in every sense of the word, rapid-fire, nonsensical ramblings that add a touch of comedy throughout.

He‚Äôs here to help you get out of the joint, and he‚Äôs awful at it. And of course, his incompetence leads to a certain villain showing up, and the two mesh well.

At this point, I was totally convinced the game was 9/10 awesomeness, both Wheatley and our villain were brilliant, superbly written and fun to interact with as we go through the typical Portal puzzles, using portals to navigate test chambers.

Where the game fell away for me was in Part 2. See, at the halfway point you get thrown out of the test chambers, I won‚Äôt elaborate on why, but suffice to say you get to use your portal gun in more open environments. You also get to incorporate ‚Äògels‚Äô into your puzzle solving, so blue allows you to bounce higher, orange lets you run fast and white lets you create portals on any surface it comes in contact with.

It‚Äôs all neat, but the expanded world doesn‚Äôt really change up the puzzles (for me), it just makes them more tedious as I now have to scour the environment for the one flipping piece I can throw a portal on, figure out the mechanics and move on. And this breaks the pacing to such an extent that I just felt it became an entire slog.

The story also, doesn‚Äôt really pick up here, because we‚Äôre treated to a history lesson ‚Äì which is nice, but in combination with the pace-breaking, it just doesn‚Äôt really entice me so much as it probably should.

This portion of the game was such a slog that it really killed the momentum of the first half, and it doesn‚Äôt help that it is more or less devoid of character interaction outside the historical blurbs. That‚Äôs what knocks the score down for me. Still, it‚Äôs a decent game, worth playing and it has an absolute army of fans that love it, so just treat my view as an anomaly in the pool, that‚Äôs science as our friendly villain would say.

6 hours of pure fun. Glad I went out of my way to replay an old classic, still better writing and game design than most games nowadays :)

I miss the tight pacing and atmosphere of Portal, but Portal 2 improves on its predecessor in nearly every other way. Test chambers are made more complex thanks to the inclusion of the new gel mechanic, the difficulty curve is properly balanced, the campaign and its story is fleshed out this time around, a CO-OP campaign is present, and P2 has a great sense of humor. Portal 2 is easily the most unique gaming experience I've ever had. It's a nice break from the droves of shooters out on the market.

It's a great classic based around platforming, logical thinking, illogical physics, and witty writing. The main story isn't terribly long, and there's an alternate story line in the two-player cooperative mode. Add on countless community created testing chambers and a workshop to create your own, its playable from ten to hundreds of hours of solid gameplay.
